class="css-15fbio0"><div class="css-1p4nyns"><p class="css-1qi8px4">transcript</p><h2 class="css-9wqu2x">Listen to ‘The Daily’: How Rudy Giuliani’s Ukraine Operation Backfired</h2><h3 class="css-eq2co1">Hosted by Michael Barbaro, produced by Alexandra Leigh Young, Luke Vander Ploeg and Rachel Quester, with help from Austin Mitchell and Jonathan Wolfe, and edited by Paige Cowett</h3><h4 class="css-qsd3hm">He was sent on a mission to clear the president’s name. In the process, he pursued a shadow foreign policy that led to an impeachment inquiry.</h4></div><dl class="css-p98d0w"><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">From The New York Times, I’m Michael Barbaro. This is “The Daily.”</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">[music]</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h"> Today, Rudy Giuliani was hired to defend President Trump against the special counsel’s Russia investigation. So how is it that Giuliani helped get Trump entangled in another investigation involving Ukraine? My colleague, Ken Vogel, investigates. It’s Thursday, October 3. Ken, I want to start by reading from some of your reporting back in May.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Please, by all means.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">You wrote a story that Rudy Giuliani, the president’s personal lawyer, was planning a trip to Ukraine in order to look into the Bidens.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Seems prescient.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">This is the quote that Giuliani gives you when you ask him about this work he’s doing in Ukraine. He says, “There’s nothing illegal about it. Somebody could say it’s improper. And this isn’t foreign policy. I’m asking them to do an investigation that they’re doing already, and that other people are telling them to stop. And I’m going to give them reasons why they shouldn’t stop, because that information will be very, very helpful to my client, and may turn out to be helpful to my government.” And then you write, “Mr. Giuliani’s involvement raises questions about whether Mr. Trump is endorsing an effort to push a foreign government to proceed with a case that could hurt a political opponent at home.”</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Yeah.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">So you had that story all the way back in May, so why is it only now that these revelations are prompting an impeachment inquiry?</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Yeah, that’s a good question. I mean, I think we understood a lot of the puzzle back then, but what we didn’t understand was the degree to which the president himself was personally involved in pushing the Ukrainians to investigate and provide dirt on the president’s political rivals. Some of that stuff had yet to happen when we first addressed this, and then only more recently have we learned about the vivid details of his involvement, and those have been really eyebrow raising.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">I wonder if you could just start at the beginning of this story.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Well, you have to go back and look at Rudy Giuliani. He, of course, was the mayor of New York City, including during the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks.</dd><dl class="css-1pwhopc"><dt class="css-xx7kwh">archived recording (rudy giuliani)</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">I’m here on behalf of a very grateful and very admiring city in saying how proud we are of the innocent men and women who were going about their lives, seeking they’re part of the American dream, when their lives were cut short by the act of cowardly terrorists.</dd></dl><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">And his leadership during that horrible time earned him the reputation of America’s mayor.</dd><dl class="css-1pwhopc"><dt class="css-xx7kwh">archived recording</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">For every single person touched by this unthinkable tragedy, there’s been one man who, above all others, has been the beacon holding this city together, and leading it forward. Rudy, Rudy. He’s the mayor of New York City, Rudy Giuliani.</dd></dl><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">And when he leaves office at the end of 2001, he’s got this great reputation, and he’s really riding high. He’s the mayor who helped New York recover from 9/11.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Right.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">And that made him a really marketable commodity as a consultant consulting on security issues. But he always kind of craved the political fight.</dd><dl class="css-1pwhopc"><dt class="css-xx7kwh">archived recording (rudy giuliani)</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">When I was mayor, there was a sign on my desk. It read, “I’m responsible.” That’s the kind of common sense accountability we need today. That’s the kind of leadership we need in Washington, and that’s why I’m running for president.</dd></dl><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">And so he takes a break from this business to run for president in 2008.</dd><dl class="css-1pwhopc"><dt class="css-xx7kwh">archived recording</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Leaders, assassinated; democracy, attacked; and Osama bin Laden still making threats. In a world where the next crisis is a moment away, America needs a leader who’s ready.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">archived recording (rudy giuliani)</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">I’m Rudy Giuliani, and I approve this message.</dd></dl><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">And that didn’t go so well.</dd><dl class="css-1pwhopc"><dt class="css-xx7kwh">archived recording (jon stewart)</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Rudolph Giuliani has dropped out. America’s mayor, John Q. 9/11, it’s over. For months, Giuliani was the frontrunner for the Republican nomination, and then people started voting.</dd></dl><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">And he returns to the business and starts to do a lot of business in Ukraine.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">And Ken, why Ukraine?</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Ukraine is the place that has drawn a lot of Western consultants and politicians and big names. It’s a place where there’s a lot of money to be made from a handful of oligarchs and wealthy interests that are looking for legitimacy that they believe that they can get from prominent Americans. And there was no more prominent American than Rudy Giuliani at that time period.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">And what are Ukraine’s security needs when it comes to someone like Rudy Giuliani?</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Ukraine has a lot of needs in this space. The most pressing concern for Ukraine is its neighbor looming to the east, Russia.</dd><dl class="css-1pwhopc"><dt class="css-xx7kwh">archived recording</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Overnight, dozens of armed pro-Russian forces seized control of the international airport and military airport in Ukraine’s Crimea region, a day after pro-Russian gunmen took over government buildings in the city and raised the Russian flag.</dd></dl><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">And so what Ukrainians are looking for and what Rudy Giuliani has in spades is both a reputation for being tough on crime, tough on terrorism, and also being able to represent sort of a de facto endorsement from the United States of America, which is something that is coveted and so important in Ukraine, to have support from the U.S. in their effort to stave off Russian aggression.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">And what is Giuliani’s relationship with Donald Trump around this period?</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">So the relationship goes back more than two decades to when Trump was actively developing real estate in New York, and Giuliani was the mayor, of course. And then they kind of overlapped in social circles and a little bit in political circles, and then their relationship takes a new turn in 2016 when a lot of the more establishment Republicans are sort of keeping their distance from Trump, who is still seen as kind of a toxic figure. Even as he’s closing in on the Republican nomination, Giuliani nonetheless decides to endorse him.</dd><dl class="css-1pwhopc"><dt class="css-xx7kwh">archived recording</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">That’s what I don’t understand. Why don’t you say, I’m Rudy Giuliani. I mean a lot in New York politics. I endorse Donald Trump.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">archived recording (rudy giuliani)</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">OK, I’m Rudy Giuliani. I mean a lot in New York politics. I endorse Donald Trump, but I’m not part of the campaign.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">archived recording</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">I don’t understand. What does that last part mean?</dd></dl><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">It’s kind of a lukewarm endorsement at first, but he’s really one of the early establishment Republicans to get behind Trump, and it pays off. When Trump is elected, Giuliani is seen as a power broker. And for a time, his name was even bandied about as a potential nominee for Secretary of State. Now, ironically, one of the reasons why he was passed over for some of these positions was that his foreign consulting work was seen as something of a liability. And so that was seen as something of a letdown, but nonetheless, he stayed an important figure in Trump world. And when the Mueller investigation started, Rudy was eventually tapped as one of President Trump’s lead defense attorneys in that.</dd><dl class="css-1pwhopc"><dt class="css-xx7kwh">archived recording (rudy giuliani)</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">There’s no reason for this investigation. There never was a good reason for it in the first place. This is just plain wrong.</dd></dl><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">And is Giuliani still doing business with these overseas security clients while he’s representing the president as a lawyer?</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Yes. And in fact, not only is he juggling both roles, but it’s arguable that his role as the president’s attorney makes him more marketable and more coveted as a consultant by some of these foreign interests who see having someone who is close to the U.S. president on their payroll as something that could be of enormous benefit.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">And how does Giuliani navigate that? As you say, it’s kind of fraught, but it’s also an opportunity.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Well, he does it in an interesting way, which is that he continues traveling the world, meeting with prospective clients, even as he is representing the president. And there are cases, including in Ukraine, where these two roles do seem to intersect.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">How so?</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Well, you have to back up and look at Trump’s obsession with Ukraine.</dd><dl class="css-1pwhopc"><dt class="css-xx7kwh">archived recording (donald trump)</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Plus the Democrats colluded on the Ukraine. So they colluded.</dd></dl><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Trump has had these theories going back to 2016 that it was actually the Ukrainians who meddled in the 2016 election.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Not Russia.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Right. And they meddled in it event to help Hillary Clinton and to hurt him. And it turns out Rudy Giuliani was hearing some of this same stuff.</dd><dl class="css-1pwhopc"><dt class="css-xx7kwh">archived recording (rudy giuliani)</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">I got information about three or four months ago that a lot of the explanation for how this whole phony investigation started will be in the Ukraine, that there were a group of people in the Ukraine that were working to help Hillary Clinton.</dd></dl><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">And so he became the perfect person to investigate these theories and use them and develop them to try to undermine the Mueller investigation.</dd><dl class="css-1pwhopc"><dt class="css-xx7kwh">archived recording (rudy giuliani)</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">And you know what’s going to happen in the next two to three months? We’re going to find out that there is a crime that was committed. It’s called conspiracy with Ukrainians. Total, total counterintelligence scam job.</dd></dl><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">And Ken, is there any validity to the Trump theory that has been picked up by Giuliani that Ukraine was trying to hurt Trump in 2016 and trying to assist the Democrats?</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">So it’s not really a simple answer to that question, Michael. There are certainly people in Ukraine who believe that there were Ukrainian officials who were too supportive of Hillary Clinton, and that some of those officials may have acted improperly in releasing this information about Paul Manafort that forced his resignation from the Trump campaign. Now, that said, there are also some theories that Trump and Giuliani have floated that are completely bogus and have been definitively debunked, and those include the idea that it was Ukraine and not Russia that actually did the hacking of the Democratic National Committee, and that Ukraine then sought to frame Russia and make it appear as if Russia was working with the Trump campaign. We know from the Mueller investigation that all of that is completely wrong.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">So what happens with this Giuliani investigation in Ukraine that’s been blessed by the president?</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">So Giuliani is reaching out to people in Ukraine. He has associates who are over there. He’s exploring some of this stuff. And he says that in the process of poking around, he comes across this other theory that might be equally beneficial to President Trump, and that involves the Bidens and their activity in Ukraine.</dd><dl class="css-1pwhopc"><dt class="css-xx7kwh">archived recording (rudy giuliani)</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Joe Biden was appointed the point man for Ukraine. Two to three weeks later, his son, Hunter, was appointed to a position on the most corrupt agency or the most corrupt business in Ukraine.</dd></dl><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">The theory is that Joe Biden, as vice president, in his capacity as the Obama administration’s point person on Ukraine pushed the Ukrainian government to get rid of a prosecutor who was widely regarded as corrupt, not because this prosecutor was corrupt and it was in the interests of the United States to help the Ukraine root out corruption, but rather because this prosecutor represented a threat to an oligarch who owned a gas company that was paying Joe Biden’s son, Hunter Biden, as a board member.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">But is there anything to this Biden theory that Giuliani is cultivating?</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">There is no evidence that Joe Biden pushed the Ukrainian government to fire this prosecutor because it would help his son or the company that was paying him as a board member. Now, that said, with everything in Ukraine, it’s not quite that simple. In fact, the people around that company were relieved when that prosecutor was fired, and that’s because they thought he was holding open the possibility of investigations of this company and the oligarch in order to be able to solicit a bribe to get him to stand down, which is, unfortunately, kind of the way that the Ukrainian prosecutorial and judicial system work.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">So what does Giuliani do next to try to actually prove these grand theories based on what feel like these teeny tiny crumbs of fact and suspicion?</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">So Rudy is working, including with Ukrainians, to try to gain traction on some of this stuff. He’s working with associates of his, and they are gathering records. They get him on the phone with some prosecutors. And then finally, in January of this year, Rudy gets a meeting in New York with the top Ukrainian prosecutor, a guy by the name of Yuri Lutsenko. And we understand that this meeting transpired over the course of a day or two with multiple sessions, many hours long. And Rudy is so enthusiastic about the information that Lutsenko is providing to him, that at one point, Rudy actually picks up the phone and calls Trump and starts to brief him on what he’s hearing.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Why? What is so exciting?</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Well, Rudy thinks he’s found a powerful Ukrainian partner to pursue these matters. And when I say pursue the matters, I don’t just mean to provide him dirt, I mean actually moving forward with investigations in Ukraine into some of these matters. And that’s quite notable, because in 2017, this same prosecutor, Yuri Lutsenko, had actually closed investigations into the oligarch who owned the gas company that employed Hunter Biden and into the company itself, and so it’s quite a notable turnabout that this prosecutor is now willing to pursue these investigations that could be of huge benefit to President Trump.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Well, help me understand why a Ukrainian prosecutor would ever want to do this kind of favor for Giuliani and for President Trump.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Well, there are a couple of theories on that, both of them have at their heart Ukrainian politics that were unfolding at the time. The president was running for re-election. This is the president who appointed Lutsenko, was seen as a patron of Lutsenko, and he was not doing very well. And so some of his allies thought that if he were able to throw President Trump a bone, give President Trump something that he wanted, President Trump might reciprocate and signal some support for the Ukrainian president. But secondarily, if the president ended up losing, Lutsenko was looking for some powerful allies in the United States who might be willing to go to bat for him with the new president and say, hey, this guy, this prosecutor, Lutsenko, is good. You should keep him. And so there is some thinking that that was motivating Lutsenko to get into bed with Rudy.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">So the understanding after Giuliani meets with Lutsenko is that Lutsenko would be pushing the investigations inside Ukraine that President Trump wants, and that President Trump would help Lutsenko’s boss get re-elected president of Ukraine. So there would be something in it for everybody.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">That’s right.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">So what ends up actually happening?</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Well, Lutsenko goes back to Ukraine, and in fact, he does take some steps towards pushing forward these investigations, and issues what is known in Ukraine as a notice of suspicion to the oligarch who own the gas company on whose board Hunter Biden sat, and it was enough to make Rudy feel pretty good about what was going on.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">And what about the other side of the understanding, that Trump would help Lutsenko’s boss?</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Yeah, that didn’t really pan out so much as some of the allies of the president had hoped. They never really got the full-throated support of President Trump that they thought that they might get if they gave Trump and Rudy Giuliani what they were seeking in terms of pushing forward these matters that Trump and Giuliani wanted investigated. And Lutsenko’s boss, the president, goes down to defeat in a landslide.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">What does that election result mean for Trump and for Giuliani?</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Well, it’s bad news for them, because they had developed this relationship with this prosecutor who was going to pursue the matters that they wanted to see pursued, and suddenly, this prosecutor’s job is in jeopardy. In fact, on election night, the president-elect signals that he wants to get rid of Lutsenko. So Giuliani and Trump are left scratching their heads, trying to figure out is there a way for them to continue this effort, and they ultimately end up taking a series of steps that lead us to where we are today.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Which is an impeachment inquiry.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Yeah.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">[music]</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h"></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">We’ll be right back. Ken, what did Giuliani and Trump do in the face of this pretty big setback in their efforts to get Ukraine to conduct these investigations that they want?</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Well, they start trying to make it pretty clear to the new president, Zelensky, and to the people around him that this is something that they feel pretty strongly about and want to see continue. And this starts, our reporting suggests, on election night.</dd><dl class="css-1pwhopc"><dt class="css-xx7kwh">archived recording</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">[NON-ENGLISH SPEECH] We did it, together.</dd></dl><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">On the night that Zelensky is triumphant in this huge landslide, he gets a call from President Trump. It’s the typical congratulatory call. But then at the end of the call, Trump expresses his commitment to work together with President-elect Zelensky and the Ukrainian people to implement reforms that strengthen democracy, increase prosperity and root out corruption. And that’s a direct quote, by the way, from the White House readout of the call.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">What do you make of that last line?</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Yeah, why that is significant is because for people who have been following this on both sides of the Atlantic, they know that when the Trump folks say corruption, what they really mean is that they want an investigation of the Bidens, and Hunter Biden’s work for this gas company, and also this idea that Ukrainians acted improperly to meddle in the 2016 election on behalf of Hillary Clinton. So even just that word, “corruption,” it is now widely understood when raised by the Trump folks to mean, we want these investigations.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">And do you think Zelensky would have understood that to mean what you just described?</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">I think he would, because his people have been following this, and they were in communication with Americans who were telling them that that’s what this means.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">And what’s your sense of what this new Ukrainian president, Zelensky, is making of Trump and how open he is to helping the president?</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">I think that once it becomes clear what Trump wants, it becomes clear to the people around Zelensky that he’s in a horrible position, really a no-win position. He knows that he needs to keep in the good graces of the United States president because Ukraine is so dependent on assistance, both military assistance and other forms of assistance and support from the United States, and if he refuses and rebuffs President Trump or Rudy Giuliani on what they want in terms of these investigations, he knows it will risk alienating the U.S. president and potentially undermining that relationship. On the other hand, he knows that if he gives the president and Rudy Giuliani what they want, it would risk alienating Democrats, and most notably, Joe Biden, who could be the next president of the United States, and that would be a real bad position for Zelensky as well if the new president of the United States is one that he has already poisoned the well with.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">So this is a very unenviable position for a brand new president of Ukraine to be in.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Yes, it is.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">So what does Zelensky end up doing.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Zelensky basically tries to avoid committing either way. He still has yet to appoint a prosecutor general to replace Lutsenko, who he has indicated that he wants to get rid of. But he says, well, you’ll just have to wait until we have this new prosecutor who’s going to come in and assess these things, and then they’ll make the decisions. Well, that does not satisfy Rudy, who wants some kind of signal sooner.</dd><dl class="css-1pwhopc"><dt class="css-xx7kwh">archived recording</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Rudy Giuliani is going on a fishing trip, as in an information gathering mission in Ukraine.</dd></dl><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">And so what Rudy does, within three weeks of Zelensky’s election, he plans a trip to Ukraine, where he intends to try to meet with the Zelensky to push for Zelensky to make some show of support for these investigations.</dd><dl class="css-1pwhopc"><dt class="css-xx7kwh">archived recording</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">The president’s personal attorney heading to Eastern Europe to encourage a foreign government to press ahead with an investigation or two that may very well damage a political rival of his clients. So let’s ask the man himself, the president’s personal lawyer, Rudy Giuliani. Mayor, great to have you with us tonight.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">archived recording (rudy giuliani)</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">How are you, Shannon?</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">archived recording</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">I’m good.</dd></dl><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Also that brings us to your reporting back in May —</dd><dl class="css-1pwhopc"><dt class="css-xx7kwh">archived recording</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">I want to read you something from The New York Times. Won’t surprise you that they’re not fans of this idea.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">archived recording (rudy giuliani)</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Oh my gosh.</dd></dl><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">— that Giuliani is about to take this trip to Ukraine to push these investigations.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">That’s right.</dd><dl class="css-1pwhopc"><dt class="css-xx7kwh">archived recording (rudy giuliani)</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">I mean, the reality is that I’m not — I wasn’t going there to encourage them to start an investigation. They have an investigation. They have an investigation of how Ukrainians helped the D.N.C. and Hillary operatives to get, in some cases, false, dirty information about the Trump campaign.</dd></dl><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">And what happens with that trip?</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Well, after we reported, it generates quite a backlash.</dd><dl class="css-1pwhopc"><dt class="css-xx7kwh">archived recording</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">The Biden campaign claims there was no wrongdoing, and Democrats pounce —</dd></dl><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Primarily from Democrats, but also from foreign policy experts across the spectrum.</dd><dl class="css-1pwhopc"><dt class="css-xx7kwh">archived recording</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">It’s an investigation designed to effect one of the candidates they fear the most, Joe Biden. And I think it’s reprehensible. OK —</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">archived recording (rudy giuliani)</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">So I’ve decided, Sharon, I’m not going to go.</dd></dl><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">And Rudy Giuliani cancels it.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">So in canceling the trip, it feels like Giuliani understands at this point that the path he’s on is problematic.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Yes and no. I think he’s conceding that it’s controversial. But what we now know is that in the weeks and months after that canceled trip, both Giuliani and Trump took several steps to continue to pressure the Ukrainians to take up these investigations. First, in mid-July, we have Trump ordering the delay and review of some assistance to the Ukrainians, $391 million worth. And then about a week later, we now know about this July 25 call between Trump and Zelensky, where Trump starts off by talking about all that the U.S. does for Ukraine, and then leads into pushing Zelensky to work with both Rudy Giuliani and the attorney general, Bill Barr, on these investigations, including the ones into the Bidens and their activity in Ukraine. And he even goes further, just so there’s no confusion, and says, and he’s upset because you had this prosecutor who was very good who was shut down, and that’s really unfair, and he says a lot of people are talking about that. Well, that prosecutor he’s talking about is none other than Yuri Lutsenko, the prosecutor with whom Rudy Giuliani had been working to push these investigations.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">So what Trump seems to be saying in reference to Lutsenko is, you should really keep that guy. He’s pretty great. Why are you being tough on him?</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Right, and at that point, Lutsenko had not yet been replaced, although Zelensky had indicated that he intended to replace him.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">It feels like so much of your reporting led right up to that phone call. Back in May, you understood Giuliani was doing this. You understood Trump seemed to be supporting it. And then you have this call.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Yeah. And we felt like we understood all the pieces here, and we felt like we understood what was being communicated. But we thought that it was being communicated with a lot of winks and nods in the traditional language of diplomacy. So it was quite stark to see it laid out, by President Trump, no less, in such very specific detail in this July 25 phone call. It was, to some degree, mind-boggling, because both Trump and the Zelensky are sort of familiar with all the issues in play here. So much of this stuff could be done more effectively and more subtly without actually coming out and making these arguments. And I couldn’t help but think as I read through this reconstructed transcript that so much of what Trump was saying, I’ve heard Rudy Giuliani say in almost these exact terms. The way that Trump’s language evoked Rudy’s was quite striking to me.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">What do you make of that dynamic between these two?</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Well, it’s sort of ironic that Rudy was brought on as Trump’s defense attorney, to help him navigate his way through the Mueller investigation, and instead, he quickly branched out and became sort of an opposition researcher, and campaign attack dog, and even a quasi-diplomat engaging with foreign governments in a way that has led Trump right into the next crisis of his presidency, in many ways, potentially worst crisis, that is now at the center of the impeachment inquiry.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">[music]</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h"></dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">I wonder, Ken, if you think that Giuliani could have pursued all of these theories, could have been digging around Ukraine just the way he was in a way that would never have led us down this path of an impeachment inquiry.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Possibly. I think that he certainly could have pursued some of these things, making it clear that he was acting in his personal capacity as the president’s personal attorney, and not acting on behalf of the president himself or the administration. That probably would have still raised hackles back in Washington. I think we probably still would have had Congressional investigations. But the minute that President Trump takes up this case personally and uses the power of the presidency to try to pressure an allying government to do his political bidding at a time when this government is facing a very real and existential threat from Russia, our common foe, is when we crossed the rubicon and got to the point where there are legitimate questions about abuse of office that undergird this impeachment inquiry.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Thank you, Ken.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">ken vogel</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Thank you.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">On Wednesday, during a visit to Italy, secretary of state Mike Pompeo acknowledged he was listening in on the telephone call during which President Trump pressured the president of Ukraine to investigate Joe Biden and his son.</dd><dl class="css-1pwhopc"><dt class="css-xx7kwh">archived recording (mike pompeo)</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">As for was I on the phone call, I was on the phone call. The phone call was in the context of — now I guess I’d been secretary of state for coming on a year and a half. I know precisely what the American policy is with respect to Ukraine. It’s been remarkably consistent.</dd></dl><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Pompeo had previously expressed ignorance of the call, raising questions about whether he misled the public about his role. Soon after, during a news conference in Washington, the chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, Adam Schiff, warned that the leaders of the impeachment inquiry would soon subpoena documents related to the Ukraine call directly from the White House, which has resisted cooperating.</dd><dl class="css-1pwhopc"><dt class="css-xx7kwh">archived recording (adam schiff)</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">So they just need to know that even as they try to undermine our ability to find the facts around the president’s effort to coerce a foreign leader to create dirt that he can use against a political opponent, that they will be strengthening the case on obstruction if they behave that way.</dd></dl><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Later on Wednesday, speaking from the White House, President Trump denounced Schiff, accusing him, without evidence, of treason, and revived his theory that Democrats had collaborated with Ukraine to hurt him during the 2016 campaign.</dd><dl class="css-1pwhopc"><dt class="css-xx7kwh">archived recording (donald trump)</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">What the Democrats did in 2016 was corrupt. And let’s see what happens. They’re more concerned with that than they are with me and impeachment. They’re trying to hide what maybe is coming. I let —</dd></dl><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">The president said it was a matter of time before information emerged that showed Democrats were engaged in a cover up.</dd><dl class="css-1pwhopc"><dt class="css-xx7kwh">archived recording (donald trump)</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">Because they know they’re guilty as hell, all right? They’re much more worried about that.</dd></dl><dt class="css-xx7kwh">michael barbaro</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h">We’ll be right back.</dd><dt class="css-xx7kwh">[music]</dt><dd class="css-zvzm1h"> Here’s what else you need to know today. The Times reports that advisors to President Trump have altered the rules for choosing delegates to next year’s Republican National Convention to ensure that there are no dissenting speeches at the closely-watched event. In several states, Republican Party officials have changed the rules so that Republican challengers who lose to Trump can no longer send delegates to the convention where they could theoretically speak out against Trump. The advisor said that the president prefers a convention free from political conflict.  That’s it for “The Daily.” I’m Michael Barbaro. See you tomorrow.</dd></dl></div></div></div></div></div></div></figure><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Along with documents and interviews with a wide variety of people in Ukraine and the United States, the latest revelations show that Mr. Trump and Mr. Giuliani ran what amounted to a shadow foreign policy in Ukraine that unfolded against the backdrop of three elections — this year’s vote in Ukraine and the 2016 and 2020 presidential races in the United States.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Despite the findings of United States intelligence agencies and the Justice Department that Russia was responsible for interfering in the 2016 election, Mr. Trump was driven to seek proof that the meddling was linked to Ukraine and forces hostile to him, even fixating on a fringe conspiracy theory suggesting that Hillary Clinton’s missing emails might be found there.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Backed by Mr. Trump, Mr. Giuliani, who once aspired to be secretary of state, sought to tar Mr. Biden with unsubstantiated accusations of impropriety, while he and associates working with him in Ukraine on the president’s agenda pursued their own personal business interests.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">With the political landscape scrambled by Mr. Poroshenko’s defeat in April and the arrival of a new cast of Ukrainian officials, the approach pursued by Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Trump undercut official United States diplomacy.</p></div><aside aria-hidden="false" aria-label="companion column" class="css-o6xoe7"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And the signals sent by Mr. Trump — long skeptical of the strategic value of backing Ukraine against Russia, its menacing neighbor to the east — complicated efforts by the new Ukrainian government to fortify itself against Moscow.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The intensifying overlap this summer between Mr. Trump’s political agenda in Ukraine and his official foreign policy apparatus is now at the center of an impeachment inquiry that will examine whether the president of the United States directed or encouraged his subordinates to lean on a vulnerable ally for personal political gain.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Among the subjects covered in a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/27/us/politics/house-democrats-impeachment-trump.html?module=inline" title="">subpoena sent Friday</a> by House Democrats to Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and demands for depositions from American diplomats was Mr. Trump’s decision to freeze a $391 million military aid package to Ukraine this summer not long before his July 25 call with Ukraine’s new president, Volodymyr Zelensky, who defeated Mr. Poroshenko this spring.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Democrats are also looking into the recall in the spring of the United States ambassador to Kiev, Marie L. Yovanovitch, a career foreign service officer who was <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/26/us/politics/yovanovitch-trump-ukraine-ambassador.html?module=inline" title="">seen as insufficiently loyal</a> to Mr. Trump by some of his conservative allies. On Friday evening, the State Department’s special envoy for Ukraine, Kurt Volker,<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/27/us/politics/volker-ukraine-resigns.html?module=inline" title=""> abruptly resigned</a>, not long after receiving a summons from House Democrats to sit for a deposition in the coming week.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Trump has dismissed the impeachment investigation as another “witch hunt.”</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In an interview on Friday, Mr. Giuliani defended his efforts to push the Ukrainians to investigate Mr. Biden, his son, Hunter Biden, and others. He asserted that he was not doing it to try to influence the 2020 presidential election, though Mr. Biden is a leading contender for the Democratic nomination to challenge Mr. Trump.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I was doing it to dig out information that exculpates my client, which is the role of a defense lawyer,” he said.</p></div><aside aria-hidden="false" aria-label="companion column" class="css-o6xoe7"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><h2 class="css-ani50b eoo0vm40" id="link-6000bb">Mixing Business and Politics</h2><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the months before the steps taken in March on the politically explosive investigations sought by Mr. Trump, Mr. Giuliani had met at least twice with the man who would become a central figure in his efforts and a target of criticism in both countries: Mr. Lutsenko, 54, Ukraine’s top prosecutor.</p></div><aside aria-hidden="false" aria-label="companion column" class="css-o6xoe7"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">First at a meeting in New York and later in Warsaw, Mr. Giuliani pushed Mr. Lutsenko for information about — and investigations into — a pair of cases of keen interest to his client.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">They included the Bidens’ activities in Ukraine and the release during the 2016 campaign of incriminating records about Paul Manafort, Mr. Trump’s campaign chairman. Mr. Giuliani said early this year he had become increasingly convinced that the Manafort records were doctored and disseminated by critics of Mr. Trump to sabotage his campaign, and later used to spur the special counsel’s investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">No evidence supports this idea and Mr. Manafort’s own retroactive <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/27/us/politics/trump-campaign-chiefs-firm-got-17-million-from-pro-russia-party.html?module=inline" title="">filings</a> under the Foreign Agents Registration Act corroborated the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://nabu.gov.ua/novyny/rozyasnennya-shchodo-zgaduvannya-imya-pola-manaforta-u-chorniy-buhgalteriyi-pr" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Ukrainian documents</a>, which also <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.apnews.com/20cfc75c82eb4a67b94e624e97207e23" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">matched</a> financial records in the United States.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Still, it was not long before Mr. Trump, sensitive to any questions about the legitimacy of his 2016 victory, began echoing Mr. Giuliani’s language about what they viewed as the Ukrainian origins of the Russia investigation.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But Mr. Trump and Mr. Giuliani had also taken a growing interest in the role played by Mr. Biden, as vice president, in the dismissal of a previous Ukrainian prosecutor who had oversight of investigations into an oligarch who had served in a previous Ukrainian government and whose company had employed Hunter Biden. No evidence has surfaced that the former vice president intentionally tried to help his son by pressing for the dismissal of that prosecutor, whose ouster was being sought by other Western governments and institutions concerned about corruption in the Ukrainian government.</p></div><aside aria-hidden="false" aria-label="companion column" class="css-o6xoe7"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In their first meeting, in January, Mr. Lutsenko <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/05/01/us/politics/biden-son-ukraine.html?module=inline" title="">later told people</a>, Mr. Giuliani called Mr. Trump and excitedly briefed him on the discussions. And once Mr. Lutsenko’s office took procedural steps to advance investigations involving the Manafort records and the oligarch linked to Hunter Biden, Mr. Giuliani, Mr. Trump and their allies aggressively promoted stories about the developments to conservative journalists at home, further turning a foreign government’s action to the president’s advantage.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“As Russia Collusion fades, Ukrainian plot to help Clinton emerges,” Mr. Trump <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/1108559080204001280" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">wrote on Twitter</a> in March, echoing the headline of one of the first such pieces by a Trump-friendly journalist.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Giuliani had seemed to slide eagerly into his new role. After his hopes of becoming secretary of state were dashed — in part, former administration officials said, because of his extensive foreign business ties — he became a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/19/us/politics/giuliani-trump.html?module=inline" title="">personal lawyer for Mr. Trump</a> when the president came under scrutiny by the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Trump was publicly lobbying his own Justice Department for an investigation of Mrs. Clinton and other Democrats. When he got no satisfaction on that score, Mr. Giuliani volunteered to take on the role of independent investigator, empowered by nothing other than Mr. Trump’s blessing.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Giuliani rejected the suggestion that he was interfering in the execution of American foreign policy, noting that Mr. Volker and the State Department eventually helped connect him with a top aide to Mr. Zelensky.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“If they were concerned, I don’t think they would ask me to handle a mission like this that’s sensitive,” he said. “I feel perfectly comfortable with what we did in Ukraine.”</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Ukraine was familiar ground to Mr. Giuliani, a former New York City mayor and presidential candidate who had built a thriving consulting and security business.</p></div><aside aria-hidden="false" aria-label="companion column" class="css-o6xoe7"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Giuliani’s activity on behalf of Mr. Trump allowed him to maintain, and increase<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">, </strong>his <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/12/12/us/politics/giuliani-consulting-abroad.html?module=inline" title="">marketability to prospective clients</a> around the world<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">.</strong> Hiring him came to be seen as a way to curry favor with the Trump administration.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That perception has been fed in Ukraine by the dual roles played by some of his business associates. Chief among them is a Ukrainian-American businessman named Lev Parnas. Mr. Parnas gathered information on the ground in Kiev about the Bidens and the Manafort documents, and he helped connect Mr. Giuliani with Mr. Lutsenko and other Ukrainians with information about the cases that interested Mr. Trump.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But Mr. Parnas also has advised Mr. Giuliani on energy deals in the region, and pursued energy deals of his own in Ukraine, while presenting himself as a representative of Mr. Giuliani on the Trump-related matters.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the early spring, as he was helping Mr. Giuliani in Ukraine, Mr. Parnas pitched a deal to the chief executive officer of the Ukrainian government-owned gas company, Naftogaz. Mr. Parnas also advised Mr. Giuliani on an effort related to a methane project in Uzbekistan for which Mr. Giuliani and his associates were to be paid at least $100,000.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Giuliani said the project in Uzbekistan did not pan out.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Parnas, a donor to Mr. Trump, rejected the suggestion that his efforts to assist Mr. Giuliani in Ukraine were related to his business, explaining in an interview on Saturday that he was funding them himself because “I think it’s outrageous that our president is getting blamed for things that he had nothing to do with.”</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Parnas said he has not done business with Mr. Giuliani in years, that his discussions with Naftogaz did not yield a deal, that he had no involvement in the Uzbekistan effort, and in fact urged Mr. Giuliani to avoid doing business there.</p></div><aside aria-hidden="false" aria-label="companion column" class="css-o6xoe7"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Giuliani’s business in Ukraine dates to 2004, when he said he was invited to give a speech there. In 2008, one of his companies <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/08/nyregion/08giuliani.html?module=inline" title="">consulted for Vitali Klitschko</a>, a former boxing and kickboxing champion who lost a bid that year to become mayor of Kiev, Ukraine’s capital, but was elected mayor in 2014.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Giuliani said he no longer represents Mr. Klitschko, but still advises him informally. He chastised the new president, Mr. Zelensky, this month for moving to limit the authority of Mr. Klitschko, who had endorsed Mr. Poroshenko in this year’s election.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Reducing the power of Mayor Klitschko of Kiev was a very bad sign particularly based on the advice of an aide to the President of Ukraine who has the reputation of being a fixer,” Mr. Giuliani <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/RudyGiuliani/status/1170176324696256512" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">wrote on Twitter</a>.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some of Mr. Giuliani’s work in Ukraine has found him on opposing sides in internal Ukrainian feuds.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In 2017, one of Mr. Giuliani’s companies <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/06/30/us/politics/ukraine-giuliani-foreign-work.html?module=inline" title="">signed a contract with Pavel Fuks</a>, a wealthy Ukrainian-Russian developer who was among the many Ukrainians <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/01/10/us/politics/ukraine-donald-trump-inauguration.html?module=inline" title="">seeking access in Mr. Trump’s Washington</a>. The contract was to help Mr. Fuks attract investment from the United States to his hometown, Kharkiv, Ukraine.</p></div><aside aria-hidden="false" aria-label="companion column" class="css-o6xoe7"></aside></div><div class="css-1sngw6j"><a class="css-1a9ghz5" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2019/09/26/us/politics/trump-ukraine-impeachment-timeline.html"><div class="css-1eoytci"><img alt="" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2019/09/26/us/trump-ukraine-timeline-promo-1569528528277/trump-ukraine-timeline-promo-1569528528277-articleLarge-v2.jpg"/></div><div class="css-1rha1bf"><h2 class="css-zd32qr">Trump’s Efforts to Push Ukraine Toward a Biden Inquiry: A Timeline</h2><p class="css-1uuihdo">A guide to the key figures and dates as President Trump and his allies pressured Ukraine to investigate his political opponents.</p></div></a></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At the time, Mr. Fuks and others, including Sam Kislin, a Ukrainian-American businessman with ties to Mr. Giuliani, had become entangled in a complicated $1.5 billion deal to buy Ukrainian government bonds.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Lutsenko, the prosecutor, blocked the deal and seized the bonds by <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kLIt_IYopnw" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">raising accusations</a> of fraud. Mr. Kislin <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OvuHQB9W9v0" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">responded</a> with suggestions that Mr. Lutsenko acted illegally.</p></div><aside aria-hidden="false" aria-label="companion column" class="css-o6xoe7"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Ukrainian media <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://24tv.ua/ru/nardep_zajavil_chto_lucenko_snjali_s_samoleta_i_ssha_annulirovali_emu_vizu_sargan_dala_objasnenie_n945308" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">reported</a> that the United States revoked Mr. Lutsenko’s visa for a time amid this dispute, though Mr. Lutsenko denied it. By January, he was able to travel to America, where he met with Mr. Giuliani to discuss investigating the Democrats.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Lutsenko’s eagerness to assist Mr. Giuliani was seen in some quarters in Kiev as an effort to win influential support to resolve his visa problem, fend off Mr. Kislin’s claims and secure American protection against potential political targeting in Ukraine.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Giuliani said he was not being paid for his work for Mr. Trump. He said he does not have any active projects at the moment in Ukraine, and that his connection to the president was not helping his business. “I don’t perceive it being down because I represent Trump, nor do I see a tremendous boost because I represent Trump,” he said.</p></div><aside aria-hidden="false" aria-label="companion column" class="css-o6xoe7"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><h2 class="css-ani50b eoo0vm40" id="link-39983173">Backing a Prosecutor, Criticizing an Ambassador</h2><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">When Mr. Lutsenko was pursuing the matters sought by Mr. Giuliani in the spring, people around Mr. Poroshenko thought it might elicit a show of support for him from Mr. Trump, who had boosted the election prospects of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/10/world/middleeast/netanyahu-trump-election-scandal.html?module=inline" title="">other foreign leaders</a>.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Or, if Mr. Poroshenko lost, the thinking in Kiev went, Mr. Trump might at least feel compelled to try to protect Mr. Lutsenko, the helpful prosecutor, from the fate that often befalls aides to defeated Ukrainian leaders: prosecution by the victors and possible jail sentences or exile. As the whistle-blower complaint pointedly noted, Mr. Zelensky had signaled during the campaign that he would replace Mr. Lutsenko if he won the election.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At first the strategy encouraged by Mr. Giuliani and pursued by Mr. Lutsenko seemed to be living up to those hopes.</p></div><aside aria-hidden="false" aria-label="companion column" class="css-o6xoe7"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Poroshenko’s allies were pleased when Mr. Trump’s associates, including the president’s son, Donald Trump Jr., and Mr. Giuliani, launched public attacks against one of Mr. Poroshenko’s perceived enemies, Ms. Yovanovitch, the United States ambassador to Ukraine.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That month, she had <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.kyivpost.com/ukraine-politics/us-ambassador-criticizes-failures-in-corruption-fight.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">criticized Ukraine’s record on corruption</a>, alluding to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.kyivpost.com/ukraine-politics/allegations-of-vote-buying-fly-before-march-31-contest.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">reports of vote-buying</a> by Mr. Poroshenko and a rival candidate, and she was seen as an impediment to the investigations sought by Mr. Giuliani. Mr. Poroshenko’s allies told people that they interpreted the Trump allies’ attacks on her as a sign that the Trump team would reciprocate if the investigations into Mr. Trump’s rivals continued.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But Mr. Trump never delivered the signal of support Mr. Poroshenko’s team was hoping for, and Mr. Poroshenko lost his re-election campaign in a landslide to Mr. Zelensky, a political neophyte.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Poroshenko’s press service issued a statement Saturday denying he solicited help for his re-election campaign. “Any attempts to link the American scandal to Poroshenko is groundless and unjustified manipulation,” the statement said. “Poroshenko has never negotiated for U.S. support for himself, but for Ukraine.”</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Zelensky <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/ChristopherJM/status/1120031231125725184" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">told reporters on election night</a> that he intended to replace Mr. Lutsenko, who had been accused of turning a blind eye to corruption, though he did not carry out the move until he formed a new government following parliamentary elections in July.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">When Mr. Trump spoke by phone to the new Ukrainian leader on July 25, Mr. Trump went so far as to complain to Mr. Zelensky about the impending replacement of Mr. Lutsenko. “I heard you had a prosecutor who was very good and he was shut down and that’s really unfair,” Mr. Trump said during the call. “A lot of people are talking about that, the way they shut your very good prosecutor down.”</p></div><aside aria-hidden="false" aria-label="companion column" class="css-o6xoe7"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><h2 class="css-ani50b eoo0vm40" id="link-4a47f4b5">Skepticism About Ukraine Policy</h2><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">From the early days of Mr. Trump’s campaign, he questioned American policy toward Ukraine, a former Soviet state that had received substantial support from the United States and the European Union. In the wake of Russia’s annexation of Crimea from Ukraine in 2014, Mr. Trump asked why the United States was so committed to the principle that seizures of territory must be opposed.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Trump called the Obama administration’s move to sanction Russia over the annexation “very confrontational,” and said in an interview with The Times in March 2016 that “it didn’t seem to me like anyone else cared other than us,” invoking his longstanding criticism that American allies do not pay their share when it comes to protecting democracy around the world.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Trump would soon develop another issue with Ukraine: Mr. Manafort’s case, which he came to view as evidence that forces in Ukraine aligned with Democrats were out to get him.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">When Mr. Zelensky, running on fighting corruption and Russia, won a lopsided victory in the presidential election on April 21, it only appears to have intensified Mr. Trump’s determination to find political advantage for himself in the country.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Within a few weeks of Mr. Zelensky’s victory, the American ambassador, Ms. Yovanovitch, was recalled, months ahead of schedule, amid the claims by Mr. Trump’s allies that she was undermining him.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Trump quizzed his aides on Mr. Zelensky, asking whether Mr. Zelensky would help him or hurt him.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“There was a friend-or-foe operation on,” said one senior United States intelligence official. “No one understood Zelensky.”</p></div><aside aria-hidden="false" aria-label="companion column" class="css-o6xoe7"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><h2 class="css-ani50b eoo0vm40" id="link-1a54d7a2">American Officials Get Increasingly Involved</h2><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">By May, according to the whistle-blower’s account, the Ukrainian leadership had been led to believe that a meeting or phone call between the two presidents would depend on “whether Zelensky showed willingness to ‘play ball’” on the political investigations.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The complaint does not identify who delivered this message to the Ukrainians. But the timing coincided with a visit to Kiev of an American delegation, led by the energy secretary, Rick Perry, for Mr. Zelensky’s inauguration. Mr. Trump had ordered Vice President Mike Pence to skip the inauguration, the whistle-blower complaint said.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">When members of the delegation returned to Washington, they stressed to Mr. Trump the importance of supporting the new Ukrainian government early on, and urged the president to demonstrate his commitment by granting Mr. Zelensky the White House visit he craved.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Trump was not convinced, saying he thought all Ukrainian politicians were corrupt and, alluding to Mr. Manafort’s case, that the country had tried to take him down.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the meantime, as the whistle-blower complaint notes, Mr. Lutsenko was seeking to remain in office under Mr. Zelensky, and was sending mixed signals about pursuing the case related to the oligarch on whose company board Hunter Biden sat.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But Mr. Zelensky would later decide to replace Mr. Lutsenko, cutting off Mr. Giuliani’s main point of access to the Ukrainian government.</p></div><aside aria-hidden="false" aria-label="companion column" class="css-o6xoe7"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It was against that backdrop that Mr. Zelensky dispatched one of his closest aides, Andriy Yermak, to open a line of communication with Mr. Giuliani.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">During a trip to Washington in July, Mr. Yermak, over breakfast at the Trump International Hotel, asked Mr. Volker for a connection to Mr. Giuliani. Mr. Volker broached the idea to Mr. Giuliani over a separate breakfast days later, and Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Yermak were soon chatting by phone.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Yet, even as these discussions were ongoing, Mr. Trump personally ordered his staff to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/23/us/politics/trump-un-biden-ukraine.html?module=inline" title="">freeze more than $391 million in military assistance</a> for Ukraine. The move, made with little explanation, puzzled and frustrated officials in the departments of defense and state, as well as members of Congress from both parties who viewed the assistance as critical to helping a close ally as it confronted Russia.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Days later, Mr. Trump and Mr. Zelensky had their <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/25/us/politics/ukraine-transcript-trump.html?module=inline" title="">fateful phone call</a>. After reminding Mr. Zelensky of the assistance the United States has provided to Ukraine, Mr. Trump asked him to work with Attorney General William P. Barr on investigations into the Bidens and other matters, according to the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2019/09/25/us/politics/trump-ukraine-transcript.html?module=inline" title="">reconstructed transcript</a>. Among them was the unfounded conspiracy theory suggesting that <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/25/us/politics/crowdstrike-ukraine.html?module=inline" title="">Ukraine rather than Russia</a> was behind the hack of the Democratic National Committee emails in 2016 and that Mrs. Clinton’s missing emails might be on a server in Ukraine.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He also repeatedly asked Mr. Zelensky to work with Mr. Giuliani.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Zelensky assured Mr. Trump that “one of my assistants spoke with Mr. Giuliani just recently and we are hoping very much that Mr. Giuliani will be able to travel to Ukraine and we will meet once he comes to Ukraine.”</p></div><aside aria-hidden="false" aria-label="companion column" class="css-o6xoe7"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The day after the call, Mr. Volker and the United States ambassador to the European Union, Gordon D. Sondland, were in Kiev meeting with Mr. Zelensky. A week later, Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Yermak <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/08/21/us/politics/giuliani-ukraine.html?module=inline" title="">met face to face in Madrid</a>.</p></div><aside aria-hidden="false" aria-label="companion column" class="css-o6xoe7"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Trump then raised eyebrows in August when he called for ending President Vladimir V. Putin’s pariah status on the global stage by <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/08/20/us/politics/trump-russia-g7.html?module=inline" title="">readmitting Russia</a> to the Group of 7 industrialized nations. Mr. Trump has quietly been urging a deal to reduce tensions between Ukraine and Russia that would pave the way for a removal of Western sanctions on Moscow, long a goal of Mr. Putin’s.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Trump himself hinted that was his goal when asked about Mr. Zelensky two weeks after the July 25 call. “I think he’s going to make a deal with President Putin, and he will be invited to the White House,” Mr. Trump told reporters.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In response to an approaching hurricane, Mr. Trump canceled a Sept. 1 trip to Warsaw at which he would have met Mr. Zelensky in person for the first time, instead sending Mr. Pence, who <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefings-statements/remarks-vice-president-pence-president-duda-poland-joint-press-conference-warsaw-poland/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">told reporters</a> that he and Mr. Trump “have great concerns about issues of corruption,” linking them to the delayed military assistance.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Only after a bipartisan outcry did the White House <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/12/us/politics/ukraine-aid-white-house.html?module=inline" title="">release the assistance</a> this month.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">After hearing on Friday that Mr. Pompeo’s records had been subpoenaed in the impeachment investigation, some State Department officials said they hoped to learn why a career foreign service officer was recalled as ambassador, and whether Mr. Pompeo was complicit in — or had opposed — putting Mr. Giuliani in touch with Ukrainian officials.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Zelensky is still waiting for his White House meeting, as he noted when he finally <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/video/world/europe/100000006734357/trump-ukraine-zelensky.html?module=inline" title="">met with Mr. Trump</a> on Wednesday in New York.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I want to thank you for the invitation to Washington,” Mr. Zelensky said at a joint news conference, “but I think you forgot to tell me the date.”</p></div><aside aria-hidden="false" aria-label="companion column" class="css-o6xoe7"></aside></div></section><div class="bottom-of-article"><div class="css-1ubp8k9"></div><div class="css-1yif149"><p>Kenneth P. Vogel and David E. Sanger reported from Washington and Andrew E. Kramer from Kiev. Mark Landler contributed reporting from London, Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Steven Erlanger from Brussels and Maria Varenikova from Kiev.</p> </div><div class="css-13ldwoe">A version of this article <script>
if (window.INSTALL_RAVEN) {
  window.addEventListener('load', function(event) {
    var includeRaven = document.getElementById("RavenInstaller");
    var script = document.createElement("script");
    script.src = "/vi-assets/static-assets/raven.min-830a6d04a55c283934dd1893d6ddc66d.js";
    script.onload = function() {
      /* eslint-disable */
// Install Raven
window.Raven.config('https://7bc8bccf5c254286a99b11c68f6bf4ce@sentry.io/178860', {
  release: vi.env.RELEASE,
  environment: vi.env.ENVIRONMENT,
  ignoreErrors: [/SecurityError: Blocked a frame with origin.*/]
}).install(); // Stop using our error handler

window.nyt_errors.ravenInstalled = true;
var regex = /nyt-a=(.*?)(;|$)/;
var id = regex.exec(document.cookie);

if (id !== null) {
  id = id[1];
} else {
  id = '';
} // Setting nyt-a as user context


window.Raven.setUserContext({
  id: id
}); // Pass collected errors to Raven

window.nyt_errors.list.forEach(function (err) {
  // weird?
  if (!err) {
    return;
  } // also weird ... ?


  if (!err.err) {
    // maybe err itself is an Error?
    if (err instanceof Error) {
      window.Raven.captureException(err, err.data || {});
    } // else { silently ignore? }

  } // just making sure ...


  if (err.err instanceof Error) {
    window.Raven.captureException(err.err, err.data || {});
  } // else { silently ignore? }

}); // Pass collected Tags to Raven

window.nyt_errors.tags.forEach(function (tag) {
  window.Raven.setTagsContext(tag);
});
    };
    includeRaven.appendChild(script);
  });
}
</script>
